newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: PRESS DIGEST - Sri Lanka Newspapers - October 22.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Sri Lanka Newspapers - October 22.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sri Lankan press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAILY NEWS
Armed men set fire to tourist bungalow at southern Yala national park, one of Sri Lanka's top tourist attractions. They abduct three park officers and get away with park vehicles.

Sri Lanka's Dr.Roland Silva, head of the Central Cultural Fund, which manages the UNESCO-Sri Lanka Cultural Triangle project, is re-elected for a third time as president of ICOMOS, the International Council of Monuments and Sites.
THE ISLAND
A massive army and police operation launched in Yala national park to track down suspected Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) guerrillas, who had infiltrated the park.

Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC), a partner in the ruling People's Alliance government, to decide on its support for government after a disagreement between SLMC leader M.H.M.Ashraff and President Chandrika Kumaratunga.
DIVAINA

Youth respond in large numbers to government call to join the armed forces. The military has said it wants to recruit 15,000 fresh cadres mainly to hold northern areas recently captured from separatist Tamil rebels.
Tourist arrivals during first six months of this year drop by 31 percent as compared to that of 1995, Central Bank statistics say.
DINAMINA
Wijayananda Dahanayake, Sri Lanka's oldest living politician and prime minister for three months, is 95 years old. The flamboyant Dahanayake once spoke for 13 hours non-stop in parliament.
LANKADEEPA
Forces destroy northern rebel radar centre, killing 40 rebels.
Rebels kill six soldiers in eastern Batticaloa district.
-- Colombo newsroom 941-434319
VEERAKESARI

Government troops kill more than 40 Tamil rebels in their attack on a large rebel naval base at Vettilaikerni south of northern Jaffna peninsula. Nine navy personnel died and 44 commandoes were wounded in attack. Troops destroyed base.
Twenty three members of parliament who visited Northern Ireland on fact-finding mission say government should included LTTE on any plans to bring peace to Sri Lanka.
THINAKARAN

Ceylon Workers Congress, a political party representing minority Tamil tea estate workers, says it will discuss with government matters concerning citizenship and right to own land and houses by the minority group.
--Colombo newsroom (941-434319)
